question: I’m going to do it seven times.
I'm going to need the car three times tomorrow.
answer: Voy a necesitar el coche tres veces mañana.

question: I don’t understand why he wants to see it twice.
answer: No entiendo por qué quiere verlo dos veces.

question: Do it six or seven times.
It’s important to eat four or five times.
answer: Es importante comer cuatro o cinco veces.

question: We (females) are going out twice today.
We want to know how much it is.
How many times are we going to need it?
How many times are you going to say it?
We don’t know how many times he can do it.
answer: No sabemos cuántas veces puede hacerlo.

question: I only have three or four.
We only need to see it twice.
Why do I only have two chairs?
Why do you only do it on Monday?
answer: ¿Por qué solo lo haces el lunes?

question: Why don’t you do it on Friday or Saturday?
answer: ¿Por qué no lo haces el viernes o el sábado?

question: I only have the car on Monday and Tuesday.
answer: Solo tengo el coche el lunes y el martes.

question: It's the first time for me.
answer: Es la primera vez para mí.

question: It's not the first time for her.
answer: No es la primera vez para ella.

question: I think that it’s the first time for you.
answer: Pienso que es la primera vez para ti.

question: We think that she only does it on Friday.
answer: Pensamos que solo lo hace el viernes.

question: The red chair is on the green table.
answer: La silla roja está en la mesa verde.

question: The black car is very fast.
answer: El coche negro es muy rápido.

question: I wouldn’t like to live in an orange house.
answer: No me gustaría vivir en una casa naranja.

question: Number six is yellow, but number eight is white.
answer: El número seis es amarillo, pero el número ocho es blanco.

question: Number four isn’t black, it’s blue and yellow.
answer: El número cuatro no es negro, es azul y amarillo.

question: Put it on the red table.
Put eight or nine beers on the table, please.
answer: Pon ocho o nueve cervezas en la mesa, por favor.

question: How’s it going? How are you?
Hello. My name’s Jessica. What’s your name?
answer: Hola, me llamo Jessica. ¿Cómo te llamas?

question: Hello Juan. How are you? What’s going on?
He’s going to do it tonight.
She’s going to know that we’re not here.
answer: Va a saber que no estamos aquí.

question: I want to find it today.
Can you tell me where it is? …because I can’t find it.
answer: ¿Puedes decirme dónde está? …porque no puedo encontrarlo.

question: Why aren’t you selling the white one?
I'm not selling it because I need it.
answer: No lo vendo porque lo necesito.

question: I'm going to sell it if he wants to buy it.
answer: Voy a venderlo si quiere comprarlo.

question: How can you buy it if you don’t know how much it is?
answer: ¿Cómo puedes comprarlo si no sabes cuánto es?

question: He has a lot of money.
If I sell the house, I’m going to have a lot of money.
answer: Si vendo la casa, voy a tener mucho dinero.

question: The problem is that she has too much money.
answer: El problema es que tiene demasiado dinero

question: She has to go to the bank because she doesn’t have (any) money.
answer: Tiene que ir al banco porque no tiene dinero.

question: We are coming/going back to the hotel at six o’clock.
answer: Volvemos al hotel a las seis.

question: You (plural) need a lot of money.
At what time do you (plural) have dinner?
We have dinner at nine o’clock.
At what time do they arrive?
At what time do you (plural) have lunch?
We have lunch at one o’clock.
They have lunch at two o’clock.
Do you (singular) want to go out with me?
They are going out at ten o’clock.
There is a woman in the room.
answer: Hay una mujer en la habitación.

question: Is there a beer on the table?
Is there a swimming pool in the hotel?
There is a lot of money in the car.
answer: Hay mucho dinero en el coche.

question: Is there (any) water in the swimming pool?
Is there a beach in Barcelona?
I can't see Pablo’s computer.
answer: No puedo ver la computadora de Pablo.

question: They don't live near my house.
answer: No viven cerca de mi casa.

question: My house is near the bank.
answer: Mi casa está cerca del banco.

question: The pool is near the hotel.
answer: La piscina está cerca del hotel.

question: The car is near the house.
answer: El carro está cerca de la casa.

question: Her car is near the house.
answer: Su coche está cerca de la casa.

question: His car is near Maria’s house.
answer: Su coche está cerca de la casa.

question: Is there a beach near the hotel?
They are selling the house near the beach.
answer: están vendiendo la casa cerca de la playa.

question: Her house isn’t near the beach
answer: Su casa no está cerca de la playa.

question: There’s a woman near the green car.
answer: Hay una mujer cerca del coche verde.

question: I would like to live near the beach.
answer: Me gustaría vivir cerca de la playa.

question: Can you speak more slowly, please?
Her house is big, but my house is nearer (more near) the beach.
answer: Su casa es grande, pero mi casa esta más cerca de la playa.

question: Do you know what this means?
No, I don’t know what that means.
answer: No. No sé lo que quiere decir eso.

question: There are three words here that I don’t understand.
answer: Hay tres palabras aquí que no entiendo.

question: Do you know what this word means?
answer: ¿Sabes lo que quiere decir esta palabra?

question: I don’t know what that word means, but I know that it doesn’t mean “swimming pool”
answer: No sé lo que quiere decir esa palabra, pero sé que no quiere decir “piscina”.

question: His name isn’t David. It’s Carlos.
answer: Su nombre no es David. Es Carlos.

question: I'm going to write your name.
We’re going to write three words in the book.
answer: Vamos a escribir tres palabras en el libro.

question: Write it there, near your name.
answer: Escríbelo allí, cerca de tu nombre.

question: Write Maria’s name near your name.
answer: Escribe el nombre de Maria cerca de tu nombre.

question: They write it too small for me.
answer: Lo escriben demasiado pequeño para mí.

question: Why are they having lunch at four o’clock?
answer: ¿Por qué están comiendo a las cuatro?

question: I get up at seven o’clock.
to get up/to get oneself up
I want to stay with you
Do you want to stay with her?
She doesn’t want to stay here
We have to get up soon.
I'm sorry but we’re staying here.
answer: Lo siento pero nos quedamos aquí.

question: We are going to stay near the hotel this afternoon.
answer: Vamos a quedarnos cerca del hotel esta tarde.

question: We are staying here because its very late and we’re tired.
answer: Nos quedamos aquí porque es muy tarde y estamos cansados/as.

question: Why do you get up at 6 o’clock?
answer: ¿Por qué os levantáis a la seis?

question: They are staying near the beach this afternoon.
answer: Se quedan cerca de la playa esta tarde.

question: Are you going to do it?
We’re going to go to Madrid.
You (plural) are going to do it for me.
They are going to arrive tomorrow.
They are going to do it too quickly/fast.
What kind of car are they going to need?
answer: ¿Qué tipo de coche van a necesitar?

question: I would like to leave soon.
You (singular, informal) have to leave now.
She doesn't want to leave on Tuesday.
You (plural) have to leave with him.
How long are you (singular, informal) staying here?
How long are you (plural) staying here?
How long are we going to stay here?
How many times are you (singular, informal) going to go to the bank today?
answer: ¿Cuántas veces vas a ir al banco hoy?

question: How many times is she going to call her?
For how how long do you (singular, informal) need it ?
I'm writing it for her because she can’t do it.
answer: Lo estoy escribiendo para ella porque (ella) no puede hacerlo.

question: Why is she writing it in green?
answer: ¿Por qué lo está escribiendo en verde?

question: I have to work on Sunday.
I can't speak now because I’m working.
answer: No puedo hablar ahora porque estoy trabajando.

question: I'm not working because it’s six o’clock.
answer: No trabajo porque son las seis.

question: She can’t do it now because she’s having lunch.
answer: No puede hacerlo ahora porque come. /… está comiendo.

question: I don't understand what you are telling me.
answer: No entiendo lo que me estás diciendo.

question: I don't understand why you are not doing it.
answer: No entiendo porque no lo estás haciendo.

question: I need to go to the cash machine.
Is there a cash machine near here?
answer: ¿Hay un cajero automático cerca de aquí?

question: There are two cash machines in the hotel.
answer: Hay dos cajeros automáticos en el hotel.

question: I have a lot of money.
I don’t have a lot of time.
I'm putting it on the table.
I leave/I am leaving (also: I go out)
I'm leaving now because I have to work.
answer: Salgo ahora porque tengo que trabajar.

question: I say/I am saying (also: I tell)
I'm saying it three times because it’s important.
answer: Lo digo tres veces porque es importante.

question: I'm not bringing it because it’s too big.
answer: No lo traigo porque es demasiado grande.

question: Don't put it on the chair!
Don’t put the money on the table.
answer: No pongas el dinero en la mesa.

question: Don’t put your phone on the chair.
answer: No pongas tu teléfono en la silla.

question: Put the beers on the small table.
answer: Pon las cervezas en la mesa pequeña.

question: Don't do it now because we’re leaving soon.
answer: No lo hagas ahora porque nos vamos pronto.

question: Do it later because we’re not staying here.
answer: Hazlo más tarde porque no nos quedamos aquí.

question: Say it more slowly because she doesn’t understand English.
answer: Dilo más despacio porque no entiende inglés.

question: Don't come if you don’t want (to).
Don't come if it’s too difficult for you.
answer: No vengas si es demasiado difícil para ti.

question: Don't do it if you don’t like it.
answer: No lo hagas si no te gusta.

question: Don't come now. It’s too late.
answer: No vengas ahora. Es demasiado tarde.

question: Don't do it today. It’s not important.
answer: No lo hagas hoy. No es importante.

question: Come here! I want to tell you something.
Do number two first. It’s easier.
answer: Haz el número dos primero. Es más fácil

question: Don't leave now if you want to see her.
answer: No salgas ahora si quieres verla.

question: I live next to the market.
My car is next to the house.
answer: Mi coche está al lado de la casa.

question: There's a a small restaurant next to the hotel.
answer: Hay un restaurante pequeño al lado del hotel.

question: It's next to the beach.
answer: Está al lado de la playa.

question: Wait for me next to the swimming pool.
answer: Espérame al lado de la piscina.

question: Wait for him in front of the hotel.
I'm going to wait for three days.
We're going to Spain for three weeks.
I'm going to wait a week and if it doesn’t arrive, I’m going to call.
answer: Voy a esperar una semana y si no llega, voy a llamar.

question: I’m leaving in a an hour.
I can do it in two hours.
I can do it in two hours.
I would like to sell it in two weeks.
answer: Me gustaría venderlo en dos semanas.

question: If you do it quickly you can do it in a week.
answer: Si lo haces rápido, puedes hacerlo en una semana.

question: We are coming back in four days (time).
If you don’t come back in an hour, I’m not going to wait for you.
answer: Si no vuelves en una hora, no voy a esperarte.

question: We can't do it this week.
We are going to do it next week.
answer: Vamos a hacerlo la semana que viene.

question: I wouldn’t like to be here next week.
answer: No me gustaría estar aquí la semana que viene.

question: I'm going to sell it next week.
answer: Voy a venderlo la semana que viene.

question: Why don't you sell it this week?
answer: ¿Por qué no lo vendes esta semana?

question: I want to buy a new house next year.
answer: Quiero comprar una casa nueva el año que viene.

question: Can I talk (speak) to you next week?
answer: ¿Puedo hablar contigo la semana que viene?

question: We can't start this week because it’s not ready.
answer: No podemos empezar esta semana porque no está listo.

question: You can give me the money next week.
answer: Puedes darme el dinero la semana que viene.

question: He's giving me the book next week.
answer: Me da el libro la semana que viene.

question: Yes. See you tomorrow. Good night.
You have more money than me (I).
She gives me more than than you.
I like the red book more than the green one.
answer: Me gusta el libro rojo más que el verde.

question: The white computer is more expensive than the black one.
answer: El ordenador blanco es más caro que el negro.

question: The restaurant is nearer the hotel than the swimming pool.
answer: EL restaurante esta más cerca del hotel que la piscina.

question: I have less time today that on Saturday.
answer: Tengo menos tiempo hoy que el sábado.

question: There is less beer than Coca Cola.
answer: Hay menos cerveza que Coca Cola.

question: There are less men than women here.
answer: Hay menos hombres que mujeres aquí.

question: I speak more Spanish than him, but less than her.
answer: Hablo mas español que él, pero menos que ella.

question: Don't tell me now tell me later (more late).
answer: No me digas ahora, dime más tarde.

question: Don't call me because I’m busy.
answer: No me llames porque estoy ocupado/a.

question: Don't start if you are not ready
answer: No empieces si no estas listo/a.

question: Don't work if you are tired.
Don't put the red one on the table.
answer: No pongas el rojo en la mesa.

question: Put the chairs on the table.
answer: Pon las sillas en la mesa.

question: The women are coming next week.
answer: Las mujeres vienen la semana que viene.

question: The women eat less than the men.
answer: Las mujeres comen menos que los hombres.

question: The yellow chairs are next to the small tables.
answer: Las sillas amarillas están al lado de las mesas pequeñas.

question: Do it once, but don’t do it twice.
answer: Hazlo una vez, pero no lo hagas dos veces.

question: Say it twice, but don’t say it three times.
answer: Dilo dos veces, pero no lo digas tres veces.

question: There are three things that I want to tell you.
answer: Hay tres cosas que quiero decirte.

question: I only do the important things.
I have a few things in the car.
answer: Tengo unas cosas en el coche.

question: I’m putting a few things behind the table.
answer: Estoy poniendo/pongo unas cosas detrás de la mesa.

question: I'm going to do it in a few days.
answer: Voy a hacerlo en unos días.

question: We are going to be here a few weeks.
answer: Vamos a estar aquí unas semanas.

question: They are going to stay in Barcelona (for) a few hours
answer: Van a quedarse en Barcelona unas horas.

question: The women are staying here a few days more.
answer: Las mujeres se quedan aquí unos días más.

question: Can you tell me where the beech is?
Excuse me, madam, Do you know where there is a bank?
answer: Perdón, señora. ¿Sabe dónde hay un banco?

question: Excuse me, sir. Do you know at what time the bus leaves?
answer: Perdón, señor. ¿Sabe a qué hora sale el bus?

question: Excuse me, madam. Can you tell me when the train arrives?
answer: Perdón, señora. ¿Puede decirme cuando llega el tren?

question: Is there a train that goes to Valencia today?
answer: ¿Hay un tren que va a Valencia hoy?

question: There are fewer buses on Sunday than on Saturday.
answer: Hay menos buses el domingo que el sábado.

question: There is a bus in the morning.
answer: Hay un bus por la mañana.

question: Is there a train in the afternoon?
There aren't (any) buses at night.
answer: No hay buses por la noche.

question: At what time does your plane leave?
At what time does her plane leave?
At what time does his plane leave?
At what time does your (formal) plane leave?
Your (formal) train arrives in the morning.
answer: Su tren llega por la mañana.

question: There is nothing in your (formal) car.
answer: No hay nada en su coche.

question: There are a few things in your room, madam.
answer: Hay unas cosas en su habitación, señora.

question: There’s a plane that goes to Mallorca next week.
answer: Hay un avión que va a Mallorca la semana que viene.

question: There is a train that goes to Alicante in the morning.
answer: Hay un tren que va a Alicante por la mañana.

question: I find it easy but it goes too slowly.
answer: Lo encuentro fácil pero va demasiado despacio.

question: I'm putting the chair on the table.
answer: Estoy poniendo la silla en la mesa.

question: I'm sorry but I don’t understand what you are saying.
answer: Lo siento pero no entiendo lo que estás diciendo.

question: I don't know what you want,
I can’t find what I want here.
answer: No puedo encontrar lo que quiero aquí.

question: What do you want to say?
I don't understand very well what you mean.
answer: No entiendo muy bien lo que quieres decir.

question: I'm sure (that) you don’t know what I mean.
answer: Estoy seguro que no sabes lo que quiero decir.

question: At what time do you arrive?
At what time does he arrive?
Does she arrive at two o’clock or at three o’clock?
answer: ¿Llega a las dos o a las tres?

question: I think (that) he she arrives at four o’clock.
answer: Pienso que llega a las cuatro.

question: I find that it’s not easy to get (arrive) to your house.
answer: Encuentro que no es fácil llegar a tu casa.

question: There is something blue on the table.
answer: Hay algo azul en la mesa.

question: Nothing is going to be ready today.
answer: Nada va a estar listo hoy.

question: There is nothing in the room.
answer: No hay nada en la habitación.

question: There is nothing in the house.
answer: No hay nada en la casa.

question: There is nothing that I want to do here.
answer: No hay nada que quiero hacer aquí.

question: I don't want to do anything.
I'm going to say something important.
There is something behind the house.
answer: Hay algo detrás de la casa.

question: There is something in front of car.
There is nothing behind the woman.
answer: No hay nada detrás de la mujer.

question: There's nothing in front of the man.
answer: No hay nada delante del hombre.

question: Is there something in the room?
There is a supermarket near the restaurant.
answer: Hay un supermercado cerca del restaurante.

question: There isn’t a market near the hotel.
answer: No hay un mercado cerca del hotel.

question: There are two supermarkets behind my house.
answer: Hay dos supermercados detrás de mi casa.

question: It's in front of the restaurant.
Don't put your car in front of the market.
answer: No pongas tu coche delante del mercado.

question: I think there is a cash machine in front of the bank.
answer: Pienso que hay un cajero automático delante del banco.
